message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presented with symptoms of heart failure and a holosystolic murmur that resolved with treatment. Mitral annular dilatation is a common cause of S3 gallop and holosystolic murmurs, often seen in postpartum women due to changes in the heart size and cardiac function during pregnancy. Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is another common cause of systolic murmurs, but it typically does not cause an S3 gallop. Mitral valve leaflet fibrosis and mitral annular calcification are also causes of mitral regurgitation, but they present with different symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The S3 gallop and holosystolic murmur suggest mitral regurgitation. Among the options, mitral annular dilatation is the most common cause of functional mitral regurgitation in the immediate postpartum period, which fits the patient's history. Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is more common in middle-aged women and presents with a more chronic course. Mitral valve leaflet fibrosis and mitral annular calcification are also chronic conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and auscultation findings suggest heart failure with a systolic murmur heard at the apex. Mitral annular dilatation can lead to mitral regurgitation and may cause a systolic murmur. Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration and mitral valve leaflet fibrosis may also cause mitral regurgitation but are less likely in this case. Mitral annular calcification can cause a diastolic murmur heard at the apex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the S3 gallop and holosystolic murmur suggest a diagnosis of acute mitral regurgitation, for which initial treatment is appropriate. Among the options, mitral annular dilatation is the most likely cause of acute mitral regurgitation postpartum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The S3 gallop and grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex suggest mitral regurgitation. Among the options, only mitral annular dilatation is associated with postpartum cardiomyopathy, which can cause mitral regurgitation. The resolution of symptoms and absence of murmur later suggest a reversible condition such as mitral annular dilatation rather than degeneration or fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The S3 gallop and holosystolic murmur indicate mitral regurgitation. Among the options, mitral annular dilatation is the most likely cause of the regurgitation, especially considering the patient's recent pregnancy. Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is a more common cause of regurgitation in older patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The S3 gallop and holosystolic murmur suggest mitral valve regurgitation. Among the options, only mitral annular dilatation is associated with postpartum mitral valve regurgitation. Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is usually chronic and progresses over time, while mitral valve leaflet fibrosis and calcification are associated with a fixed murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The S3 gallop and holosystolic murmur suggest mitral regurgitation. Among the options, only Mitral annular dilatation is likely to cause lactation-induced heart failure. The resolution of symptoms and the disappearance of the murmur after treatment with intravenous furosemide and captopril support the diagnosis of mitral regurgitation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and findings on cardiac examination suggest congestive heart failure, and the presence of an S3 gallop and a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex indicate mitral regurgitation. Mitral annular dilatation is the most likely explanation for this finding in a postpartum patient with no history of major medical illness. Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is a common cause of mitral regurgitation, but it is less likely to occur in a young patient with no history of major medical illness. Mitral valve leaflet fibrosis and mitral annular calcification are also less likely causes of mitral regurgitation in this patient population.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the S3 gallop and the holosystolic murmur heard at the apex suggest mitral regurgitation. Among the options, only mitral annular dilatation can cause mitral regurgitation. The fact that the symptoms resolved and the murmur disappeared after treatment also supports this diagnosis.
